title.narrative: Covid-19 response activities of the Palestine Red Crescent Society in the occupied Palestinian Territory

description.narrative:
On 31 December 2019, the Government of China reported a cluster of cases of pneumonia of unknown cause in Wuhan, Hubei Province. A novel corona virus was identified and has been named COVID-19. On 30 January, World Health Organization (WHO) declared the COVID-19 outbreak a public health emergency of international concern. On March 11, WHO declared the COVID-19 outbreak a pandemic.
As of 6th April, a total of 246 Palestinians have been confirmed to have COVID-19, 234 in the West Bank (excluding East Jerusalem Palestinians), and 12 in the Gaza Strip. Only one person died from COVID-19 on 25 March in the West Bank until April 6th . The majority of people do not present critical symptoms and 23 people have recovered. While the current number of people detected in the oPt remains low, this may reflect the limited testing capacity. Contact tracing has been initiated for all confirmed cases. (Source: WHO)
Although the Palestinian Authority (PA) has taken strict measures early enough, and was able to some extent to contain the situation and prevent rapid spread of it in the oPT, stopping at around 100 cases; the real challenge started when the Palestinians workers in Israel started coming back to oPT after the spread of COVID-19 where the cases so far are more than 7000. The total number of workers amount to more than 45000 worker, and the PA is struggling to receive them, making tests for them and ensure the quarantine measures are taking place; especially as the cases among them have started to increase in tens. The PA fears a widespread of COVID-19 in the oPT that cannot be dealt with, given the Palestinian MoH incapability of dealing with hundreds of cases due to the lack of the needed capacities in the available hospital, that would lead to a collapse in the health system in Palestine.
The capacities of the MoH as indicated in their latest report for WB and GZ include: a total of 375 ICU beds, and 295 ventilators only. Therefore, the Government of Palestine is taking the strictest measures at the earliest stages possible.
In light of the above, the Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas extended the State of Emergency in Palestine for 30 days starting April 6th. This was accompanied by stricter measures on the various levels, such as movement hours, testing cases, etc.
The number of cases continues to grow, and the threat of further spread within the region and globally remains high. The COVID-19 outbreak and response has been accompanied by a massive “infodemic” that makes it hard for people to find trustworthy sources and evidence-based guidance when they need it. Understanding of this virus and the resulting outbreak is rapidly evolving. Information gaps have led to misconceptions, stigmatization, rumours and uncertainty that are currently partially filled by speculation in scientific and public communities, contradicting evidence-based health information and, in extreme cases, stopping people from protecting themselves and undermining the correct health seeking behaviours.

PRCS COVID-19 Response will focus on the training of staff and volunteers; disseminating key public health messages through activating volunteers at a community level applying alternative approaches in lockdown situation, the use of social media, and protecting the EMS staff and volunteers through the provision of PPEs as well as the preparedness of various PRCS hospitals to be used as quarantine or even treatment centers in an advanced or complicated scenario. Relief and PSS activities will address areas not reached by other partners and target the most vulnerable communities.
As any pandemic, COVID-19 operations shall begin and end in communities; who shall be engaged and trained and prepared to a quick and easy spreading virus. Hence, PRCS relies on its long-standing policy and strategy of Decentralization and Resilience of communities. The added value of having the largest spread in the oPT through volunteers, branches and sub-branches will support the response plan operations of COVID-19. PRCS mobilizes all of its assets and human resources to achieve its objectives and reach the last mile.
Palestine Red Crescent Society in the occupied Palestinian territory and the Netherlands Red Cross

To ensure a rapid, efficient and coordinated response, the PRCS focuses on the following components: 1. Preparing and protecting EMS, hospital and primary health clinic staff. 2. Awareness and dissemination of key public health messages and psychosocial support. 3. Provision of 15000 food parcels to vulnerable families including labourers returning from Israel. 4. Ensure the wellbeing and coverage of basic needs of vulnerable families especially those with People with Disabilities between its members. 5. Provide PSS to families and awareness for violence prevention. 6. Provide NCD medicines for vulnerable chronic patients, unable to move because of the lockdown/curfew.

Support to the COVID-19 response plan of the Palestine Red Crescent in Lebanon.

description.narrative:
From their mandate, PRCS/L enjoys full acceptance, respect and access within the areas under their jurisdiction, providing services in the Palestinian camps and its outskirts. With regard to their COVID-19 response plan, PRCS/L is the main coordinating actor between Palestinian factions and stakeholders in Lebanon, and they are working closely together with the Lebanese Red Cross. LRCS and PRCS/L have set-up protocols for transportation of COVID-19 cases (agreed with PLO, Palestinian embassy, UNRWA and other Palestinian authorities within the camps). This means PRCS/L will facilitate access to LRCS ambulances inside the camps for transportations. PRCS/L themselves have 17 ambulances and their EMS staff and volunteers will be trained by Emergency Medical Teams of LRCS, in case PRCS has to start doing quarantined transportations. Currently the focus is on containment, working risk communication and community engagement (RCCE) activities within the camps, informing people about the importance of screening, isolation and treatment, and ensuring that in close coordination with LRCS and UNWRA suspected patients are transported to the designated hospitals outside the camps.
An epidemic outbreak within the camps would go beyond the capacity of PRCS/L. If this would happen, PRCS/L could use their 5 hospitals as treatment places, isolating and designating an area of the hospital for monitoring and treatment of moderate COVID-19 cases. At the same time, PRCS/L will continue RCCE activities in the communities on handwashing, social distancing, recognising symptoms and home-based care.
Palestine Red Crescent in Lebanon and Netherlands Red Cross
Support to the COVID-19 response plan of the Palestine Red Crescent in Lebanon.

The Lebanon branch of the Palestine Red Crescent (PRCS/L) is the only mandated secondary health care service provider for the 500.000 Palestinian refugees living in Lebanon, and they are facing extreme challenges to maintain the delivery of these mandated services. UNRWA used to be one of the main donors of PRCS/L, covering 85% of the costs of patient referrals to the 5 hospitals PRCS/L is running. However, due to funding challenges UNWRA on 1 March officially communicated to PRCS/L that they will reduce the coverage of these referrals to a minimum. This has a massive impact on the ability of PRCS/L to sustain the life-saving services provided in their 5 hospitals.
The current economic crisis in Lebanon is exacerbating the already vulnerable financial situation of PRCS/L; with an unpegged exchange rate and the capacity of suppliers deteriorating, not being able to maintain bid validity at government rate, the capacity of PRCS/L to sustain the regular supply of consumables and life-saving equipment to their hospitals is impeded heavily.

title.narrative: Strengthening URCS COVID-19 preparedness and respone for effective risk mitigation and detection to control the spread of COVID-19 in high risk border districts.

description.narrative: Border districts of Busia, Tororo (Malaba), Rakai (Mutukula), Amuru (Elegu), Ntungamo (Mirama Hills), Isingiro (Kikagati), Lamwo, Adjumani, Kasese, Bundibugyo, Ntoroko, Kisoro and Kanungu.
People crossing border points and local communities living near the border points.

The whole country is at risk of COVID-19 outbreak, but the national taskforce has listed 42 districts along the borders and those along the truck routes as category 1: high risk and they have been prioritized for response interventions.

To strengthen the existing URCS COVID-19 preparedness and response structures and mechanisms to implement timely and effective risk mitigation, detection and response measures to control spread of COVID-19 in high risk border districts.

• Conduct risk communication, social mobilization, community engagement and accountability to communities along the border in 3 border districts of Ntungamo, Lamwo and Adjumani • Conduct screening and risk communication at 3 border entry points (Mirama Hills in Ntungamo; Ngom oromo and Madi opei in Lamwo). • Provide PPE for the volunteers and IPC supplies at the 3 POE and the community along these borders including quarantine centers. • Provide WASH equipment and supplies. Set up of handwashing points will be supported through provision of tippy taps, soap and hand washing demonstrations by the volunteers. • Enhance capacity of URCS to be able to prevent, prepare and respond to COVID-19.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Response Haiti

description.narrative: Prevent and reduce the risk of transmission of COVID-19 through effective coordination, implementation of preventative measures and the dissemination of basic information to local communities by mobilizing the Haitian Red Cross volunteer network. This project is aimed at achieving the following results: 1. The operational capacity of the various state and non-state institutions involved in the COVID-19 response in the target municipalities is strengthened through enhanced coordination and the implementation of preventative measures. 2. Public awareness on COVID-19 is increased through risk communication and community engagement (RCCE) activities. 3. The response capacities of Haitian Red Cross and other institutions in the target municipalities are strengthened through the reactivation of the Community Based Epidemiological Surveillance system (SEBAC) and the training of volunteers and staff.
The Covid-19 response project in Haiti, funded by MoFA through the DRU.

To implement Covid-19 response activities in Haiti. A significant increase in the number of COVID-19 cases is expected from mid-April onwards. The combination of COVID-19, the ongoing political and socioeconomic crisis and the upcoming cyclonic season, unfortunately paint a very grim picture for the people in Haiti for the months ahead.

Covid-19 response in Benin

description.narrative: Benin Red Cross and Netherlands Red Cross

Benin recorded its first case of COVID-19 on March 16, 2020 in Cotonou. Since then, despite the state’s measures to halt the spread of the pandemic, new confirmed cases have been recorded. The vast majority of cases are concentrated in the southern and most populous part of the country. The government is aware of the gravity of this pandemic and of the importance of the WHO directives concerning containment and mass screening. However, the government lacks the means to implement all the WHO recommendations and relies on the responsibility of the populations to respect and abide by the government measures. Yet, despite awareness campaigns carried out by the government, compliance with the measures remains problematic because of language barriers, the lack of access to conventional media (TV and radio) and social networks. In addition, understanding and abiding to the measures is often very challenging for a population reliant on the informal sector to ensure their livelihoods.
Many challenges lie ahead in terms of epidemiological surveillance of the virus within the communities; stigma, non-compliance with the government measures, fear of the population, rumors, and disinformation. Gender may impact the way in which health messaging can be distributed and be taken up. This needs to be addressed with dissemination of health information of the authorities to the population and psychosocial support to the first responders, volunteers, and vulnerable groups. Communication at the community level must be reinforced, as well as community-based surveillance. And because of the existing teams for contact monitoring and psychosocial support of the Benin Red Cross, the government requested specific expertise in these areas.

The overall objective of this operation is to contribute to the prevention and reduction of the immediate risks associated with the spread of COVID-19 in Benin by mobilizing the Benin Red Cross volunteer network.

The project is aimed at achieving the following results:
Result area 1: Community based surveillance systems vis-à-vis COVID-19 are strengthened by the Benin Red Cross 1) The population adopts preventive hygiene practices to control the rate of covid-19 infections and rumors are minimized 2) The community-based monitoring of the local health system is reinforced by volunteers of the Benin Red Cross
Result area 2: Benin Red Cross provides relevant response activities for those affected by COVID-19 1) Contaminated spaces identified are effectively disinfected 2) Benin Red Cross assists with safe burial practices 3) Benin Red Cross is ready to provide psychosocial support to people infected and affected by COVID-19
Result area 3: Reinforcement of the intervention capacity of Benin Red Cross in prevention and response to COVID-19 1) Appropriate measures are taken to protect staff and volunteers 2) Benin Red Cross has adequate human and material resources for operations management 3) The response is continuously monitored and evaluated

Covid-19 Response Malawi

description.narrative: 6 districts out of the 28 in total, including Lilongwe.

The aim of the Red Cross Movement Covid19 Preparedness and Responds Project is to enable Malawi Red Cross Society (MRCS) being well prepared and ready to respond to Covid19 preventing the onset of the disease and contributing to control mechanisms to prevent spread of the disease at all levels in Malawi.

The objective is to support the Red Cross Movement Covid19 Preparedness and Response Plan with funding channeled through the Danish Red Cross (DRC), who is leading the consortium. The project focuses on health; specifically on raising of awareness and enhancement of knowledge of key aspects of COVID-19 and equipping MRCS staff, volunteers and stakeholders. Furthermore, the sensitization and mobilization of at risk communities on prevention and control measures. In addition MRCS capacity is strengthened to support government infrastructure and services related to COVID-19.

Till this date there are 33 confirmed cases of which 22 in Lilongwe and with a total death toll of 3. This project will in high risk areas make use of scenario 2 such as Lilongwe and elsewhere scenario 1 with a scale up to level 3 when and if needed.

Lebanese Red Cross' response to the COVID-19 pandemic in Lebanon

description.narrative: 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) is a virus identified as the cause of an outbreak of respiratory illness first detected in Wuhan, China. Early on, many of the patients in the outbreak in Wuhan, China reportedly had some link to a large seafood and animal market, suggesting animal-to-person spread. However, a growing number of patients reportedly have not had exposure to animal markets, indicating person-to-person spread is occurring. At this time, it’s unclear how easily or sustainably this virus is spreading between people. Following the outbreak of 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) and after the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the outbreak as a global emergency on January 31, 2020, national and international efforts has been made to ensure proper preparedness and response.
Lebanese Red Cross and Netherlands Red Cross
Response of the Lebanese Red Cross to the COVID-19 pandemic

Strategic Objectives: 1. Support in risk communication, community engagement and public awareness; 2. Support in case detection and identification at level dispatch; 3. Ensure safe and efficient transportation of suspected and confirmed cases; 4. Maintain provision of LRCS services to beneficiaries in a safe and effective manner while ensuring the safety of LRCS staff and volunteers

COVID-19 UNICEF Emergency Dpt

description.narrative: L'expérience a démontré qu'Haiti est très vulnérable aux épidémies, en témoigne l'epidemie de cholera au cours de laquelle plus de 820 000 cas suspects on été recensés entre 2010 et 2019 et qui a fait plus de 10 000 morts selon le MSPP. Cette pandemie de Covid-19 s'inscrit donc dans un contexte sanitaire déjà très précaire avec des conséquences potentiellement dramatiques pour la population haïtienne, particulièrement les ménages les plus vulnérables qui ont vu leur situation socio-économique et sanitaire se dégrader continuellement depuis le début l'année 2018.

Les enfants, les femmes et leurs familles dans les zones rurales et urbaines, utilisent des services améliorés d'eau, assainissement et hygiène équitables et durables, contribuant à la réduction de l'incidence de la Covid-19 en Haïti.
Population la plus vulnerable dans le département du Sud et Sud-Est en Haïti.
Surveillance et sensibilisation auprès des communautés concernant la pandemie Covid-19 dans les départements du Sud et Sud-Est, Haiti.

People reached
COVID-19 Response & Capacity Strengthening Khartoum

description.narrative: 98,000 persons and indirectly to over 790,000 individuals in Khartoum.
Beneficiaries are mainly from the communities in Omdurman city, Umbada localities and Albougaa administrative unit.

Support to SRCS Khartoum Branch to slow down the fast spreading COVID-19 pandemic and to support the Branch with capacity strengthening. The project will directly deliver assistance to approximately 98,000 persons and indirectly to over 790,000 individuals. In the initial phase, beneficiaries will majorly be from the communities in Omdurman city, Umbada localities, Albougaa administrative unit. SRCS volunteers, health facilities clients and staff are among the beneficiaries.

The most affected locality by COVID-19 in Sudan is Khartoum (city) with 8168 confirmed cases. The state has 239 Primary Health Care centers (PHCs) and only 54% of them are functional. The reasons for non-functioning PHCS is not yet known. Khartoum isolation centers have bed capacity of 646 while ICU bed capacity is 18. This scenario shows the low capacity of the health system in Khartoum (city) to respond to an increasing ratio of COVID-19 cases.

The proposed intervention will support 9 health centres in Khartoum with trainings for staff and volunteers, provision of safe water, PPE’s, hygiene promotion in the community and surveillance. In addition to the COVID-19 response, the proposed intervention also supports the Khartoum branch of SRCS in capacity strengthening, financial sustainability and volunteers management to ensure long-term sustainable support.

South Sudan RC COVID-19 Response Plan Contribution NLRC

description.narrative: The number of COVID-19 cases are in sharp daily rise in South Sudan since the beginning 2021, which raises alarm. As of 11 Feb 2021, the number of confirmed cases is 4,960 (of which 3,729 has recovered ) with a death toll of 71 . For a fragile country like South Sudan where only 41% of the population has access to basic water supply and 11% has access to sanitation coverage , COVID-19 is more than a health crisis and poses additional risks to livelihoods and access to basic services.

This project will contribute to: Output 1 - Improved access to safe water through rehabilitation of water points Output 2 - Improved access to sanitation facilities through rehabilitation/ construction of toilets Output 3 - Increase community awareness on COVID-19 transmission through appropriate hygiene promotion activities.
This proposal will target 10,000 most vulnerable people in Juba with an objective of increasing access to basic WASH services thus contribute to reduction of COVID-19 transmission.

To contribute to the prevention and control of COVID-19 community transmission through increased access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene services including risk communication and awareness building through behavour change communication approach. This objective will be achieved through rehabilitation/installation of WASH facilities in the targeted communities as well as in the schools. This project will contribute to earmarked WASH activities within SSRC National COVID Plan.

title.narrative: Other - People reached

Building community resilience to acute shocks and chronic stresses in Terekeka County, South Sudan

description.narrative: A Resilience Index Measurement and Analysis methodology was applied in 2019 to understand how South Sudanese households cope with shocks and stressors. According to the Resilience Capacity Index Terekeka County has one of the lowest resilience capacities in South Sudan. In Terekeka County about 136,600 people are in great humanitarian need (55%). The most prevalent shocks experienced by households, such as unusually high food prices, irregular rains, prolonged dry spells, reduced income for household members, and insecurity or violence, have a significant negative effect on resilience. The number of people in great humanitarian need is likely to further increase in 2020 because of increased mobility amongst IDPs and spontaneous return of refugees.

Enable 8670 Households - 43,350 vulnerable people to build resilience to acute shocks and chronic stresses through targeted programming to increase access to WASH basic services and livelihoods and reduce protection concerns in Terekeka County (South Sudan) in a span of one and half years.

This Intervention will target 4 Payams and 11 Bomas in Terekeka County: 1. Terekeka (Buko, Nyikabor, Juba Bayak and Bor) 2. Muni (Yukara and Gabuta) 3. Reggo (Mogiri Guk, Buju and Buranga) 4. Nyori (Lwoki and Nyori)

title.narrative: Other - People reached
People reached
Conflict and Pandemic Preparedness and Response Capacity in Ethiopia

description.narrative: Ethiopia is among countries highly vulnerable to man-made and natural hazards such as conflict, drought, flood, epidemic and pandemic. Conflict and violence in Ethiopia lead to massive displacement and high humanitarian needs. Government reforms have fueled the increasingly ethnically motivated and politicized tensions. There is a high risk that the national election in 2020 will ignite additional outbreaks of violence, likely affecting 3.3 million people nationwide. Moreover, the current COVID-19 pandemic is another risk the country is facing. Humanitarian agencies, including the Ethiopian Red Cross Society (ERCS), have minimum preparedness and response capacities in place to meet the immediate needs, while facing increased difficulty in accessing people in need due to shortage of PPEs, security constraints and the politicization of the situation. The proposed Action will contribute to the delivery of a timely and principled humanitarian response to people affected by conflict and COVID-19 in Ethiopia, by strengthening the response preparedness capacity of the ERCS to deliver a timely and principled response to humanitarian needs in conflict and other hazards (including COVID-19). The Action will target the ERCS branches in three regions: Amhara, Oromia and SNNP. Activities address technical capacity, systems and procedures, and logistics and include topics that are critical in a context of conflict and other hazards, such as contingency planning; communication and coordination; safer access and protection, and early warning/early action. By supporting the development and countrywide familiarization of key response preparedness policies and guidelines, the Action also contributes to the ERCS’s overall capacity. This Action is a partnership between the Netherlands Red Cross (NLRC) (lead), ERCS, Danish Red Cross (DRC) and the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC).

title.narrative: Conflict and Pandemic Preparedness and Response in Ethiopia

description.narrative: Amhara Regional State Africa ETHIOPIA Oromia Regional State Africa ETHIOPIA Sidama Regional State Africa ETHIOPIA Southern National and Nationalities Regional State (SNNP) ETHIOPIA Tigray ETHIOPIA

Concerning ‘Conflict and Pandemic Preparedness and Response Capacity in Ethiopia’ The proposed Action will contribute to the delivery of a timely and principled humanitarian response to people affected by conflict and COVID-19 in Ethiopia, by strengthening the response preparedness capacity of the ERCS to deliver a timely and principled response to humanitarian needs in conflict and other hazards (including COVID-19).
In January 2021 the project received a top-up of Euro 500,000 from ECHO for response activities in Tigray.

Ethiopia is among countries highly vulnerable to man-made and natural hazards such as conflict, drought, flood, epidemic and pandemic. Conflict and violence in Ethiopia lead to massive displacement and high humanitarian needs. Government reforms have fueled the increasingly ethnically motivated and politicized tensions. There is a high risk that the national election in 2020 will ignite additional outbreaks of violence, likely affecting 3.3 million people nationwide. Moreover, the current COVID-19 pandemic is another risk the country is facing. Humanitarian agencies, including the Ethiopian Red Cross Society (ERCS), have minimum preparedness and response capacities in place to meet the immediate needs, while facing increased difficulty in accessing people in need due to shortage of PPEs, security constraints and the politicization of the situation. The proposed Action will contribute to the delivery of a timely and principled humanitarian response to people affected by conflict and COVID-19 in Ethiopia, by strengthening the response preparedness capacity of the ERCS to deliver a timely and principled response to humanitarian needs in conflict and other hazards (including COVID-19). The Action will target the ERCS branches in three regions: Amhara, Oromia and SNNP. Activities address technical capacity, systems and procedures, and logistics and include topics that are critical in a context of conflict and other hazards, such as contingency planning; communication and coordination; safer access and protection, and early warning/early action. By supporting the development and countrywide familiarization of key response preparedness policies and guidelines, the Action also contributes to the ERCS’s overall capacity.

Strengthening the Preparedness and Response Capacity of ERCS in particular in Amhara, Oromiya and SNNP regions to deliver a timely and principled response to humanitarian needs of conflict-and pandemic/epidemic (COVID-19) affected populations with unreserved access.

title.narrative: Other - People reached
People reached
DATA SUPPORT MENA 2021

description.narrative: NLRC, through its 510 initiative provides remote technical assistance to RCRC national societies. IFRC will be involved to cooridnate the support proivded to countries in the MENA region and will itself also receive data & digital support from NLRC/510.
NLRC/510 IFRC MENA region RCRC NS in the MENA region

The support provided is flexible and demand driven. It also follows a human centered process, ensuring that client needs and the local context drive the definition of NLRC's support. The identified needs must be realistic in scope, must be within the ability of the NLRC to answer and finally, there must be a clear commitment from the recipient NS to engage proactively with NLRC throughout the project. The countries that will ultimately receive support through this project have not yet been determined but are expected to primarily be in the MENA (Middle East and Northern Africa) regions. Based on the knowledge collected and the changing dynamic of the pandemic, we anticipate that recipient national societies will request data and digital support in the following (generic) areas: 1. Continuation of crucial data & digital support for NS for emergency support products 2. Support NS data and digital support for Covid vaccination campaign. 3. Compounding disasters: disaster response complicated by to the Covid pandemic 4. Cash IM support

Through the 510 Data & Digital Team NLRC assists 19 RCRC National Societies in their short-term preparedness and response to COVID-19 and supported their operational continuity, through data and digital. This support was made possible through a 12-month block funded project that started implementation on 1 April 2020. At the time of writing (2 months before the end of the project) several countries are encountering a renewed increase of infections. New uncertainties are introduced by the virus mutations, underlining that the Covid response phase is far from over. With the approval of several vaccines and the start of vaccination campaigns in countries around the world, the focus is beginning to shift from response to recovery. The road however remains long and based on the achievements of the 2020 global COVID program and the feedback received the added value of continued data and digital support beyond the current project's end date, 31 March 2021, is clear.

title.narrative: Other - People reached
People reached
Additional COVID-19 support PRCS/L

description.narrative: In its five areas of operations in Lebanon, Palestine Red Crescent Society – Lebanon Branch (PRCS-L) provides health and ambulance services to Palestinian refugees and all other vulnerable in need, distributed in 12 official camps recognized by UNRWA and a number of informal gatherings that do not benefit from UNRWA services. The total number of registered Palestinian refugees in Lebanon is 470,000. The number of who are still present in Lebanon is 270,614. PRCS-L suffers from a shortage of ambulances in Tyr area – South Lebanon. This area contains three official Palestinian refugee camps, namely (Al-Bass, Rashidiya and Burj AlShamali). These camps are inhabited by about 55,000 Palestinian refugees, in addition to many informal settlements in the same area, which are inhabited by approximately 23,000 refugees, and in addition to the Palestinian refugees from Syria and Syrians.

In order for PRCS-L to continue its life saving operations, funding has been made available for the procurement of two ambulances (2 times 25.000 EUR). The ambulances will enable PRCS-L to transport patients as safely and quickly as possible. In addition, an amount of 80.000 EUR has been made available to support PRCS-L in its current emergency response operations (including COVID-19). This support includes the rehabilitation of the Balsam hospital in Rashidiyeh camp (30.000 EUR) and for the procurement of medical equipment, medicines and medical supplies (50.000 EUR).

PRCS-L currently only has two ambulances in this area. One of them is in a poor condition. In addition to the scarcity of Palestinian organizations that operate ambulances in the area. All of the above casts its weight on the shoulders of the Palestinian society in general on one hand, and on the shoulders of the PRCS-L on the other hand as it operates hospitals and demands of quickly transfer the Palestinian patients when they need that. Hence, the need for two new fully equipped ambulances to transport patients safely and properly with the ability to preserve their lives.

Contribution to the Sahel Cluster Operational Plans of 2021 and 2022

description.narrative: Contribution to the Sahel Cluster Operational Plans of 2021 and 2022 NLRC funding source: Block Grant 2018-2021 - Chronic Crises

The rapid deterioration of the Sahel crisis has driven humanitarian needs across the region to unprecedented levels. In 2020 a new record high of 24 million Sahelians in need of life-saving assistance and protection due to conflicts, climate shocks, chronic vulnerabilities, and endemic poverty1. This situation led more people than ever before to flee their homes. In the Sahel, climate change, food insecurity, poverty, conflict, and violence have converged and are overwhelming the lives of millions of people. Mounting humanitarian need is the most visible symptom of the triple peril of severe-weather related disasters, poverty and insecurity plaguing the region. COVID-19 has made the situation even worse.

SHO campaign contribution to LRCS Response on Beirut Explosion

description.narrative: Lebanese Red Cross and Netherlands Red Cross

On August 4th 2020, an explosion took place in the harbor of Beirut, leading to more than 4000 people being injured, and more than 100 deaths. Many houses are destroyed, and the destruction of the harbor complicates arrival of goods most necessary in times of economic crisis and the covid-19 pandemic. In response a SHO (GIRO 555) campaign was organized within the Netherlands. This project facilitates a contribution from the SHO campaign to the LRCS Response on the Beirut Explosion.
SHO campaign contribution to LRCS Response on Beirut Explosion

The project is a contribution from the SHO campaign to the appeal of the Lebanese Red Cross in response to the 2020 Beirut Explosion. The following clusters will benefit from the SHO campaign: a) Cash (Cash Voucher Assistance to beneficiaries) b) Health (Equipment, consumables and other material for emergency medical services, blood transfusion centers, medical social, operational costs for responding to needs) c) Basic Assistance & WASH

title.narrative: Other - People reached

LRC COVID-19 health support

description.narrative: In light of the drastic situation the Health care system in Lebanon is facing in responding to the high numbers of COVID-19 patients and after declaring a state of alert in the Health Sector in the country, LRC proposed a joint intervention with the relevant ministries and syndicate of doctors and nurses to firstly decrease the pressure on the hospitals that are flooded with patients and cannot anymore provide care (no ICU beds available, no Oxygen tanks nor appropriate medical equipment etc.)

The LRC in coordination with the relevant authorities and stake holders identifies 2 immediate saving lives actions in the communities to be implemented through this plan: 1. Support Fees for Doctors and Nurses in the Governorates which list will be provided by the local authorities: This plan is about involving the doctors and nurses in the Governorate to help and monitor the COVID-19 cases especially those that could be treated at home therefore decreasing the pressure in the hospitals; LRC will then transport urgent cases based on the assessment provided. For that, a policy is being put in place as well as a search for an appropriate center in a hospital in the Governorate or in the Operation Room of the Governorate. Equipment, medicines, and consumables for patients at home will be provided for free with the support of the local authorities. 2. Support Fees for infectious disease doctors to provide specialize follow up together with the in the ground teams: Infectious Disease doctors will provide specialize medical support over the country to the on the ground teams and patients that require more specialized assistant. At least 2 Doctors will support each governorate. These 2 actions will contribute to decrease the pressure in the hospitals where LRC will transport only urgent cases based on the assessment provided.
To Support the Health Care System in Lebanon to response in the local communities to the increasing number of Covid-19 cases over the country

title.narrative: 3FM SR 2020: COVID-19

description.narrative: The Red Cross focusses on national- and international aid, aiming to relieve the immense pressure on the health care systems and striving to ensure that everyone receives the medical attention that they need wherever and whenever necessary, so also during the corona crisis. The Red Cross has two main objectives: 1. To support and enhance health care centres, doctors’ practices and hospitals by offering them a helping hand, providing logistical support and by sharing knowledge and resources. This gives them more time with their patients and gives them the opportunity to help more people in need. 2. To fight the rise of the coronavirus and to cut down the number of infections, thereby reducing the number of patients in need of medical attention.

title.narrative: Help the Helpers, Medical Aid during COVID-19 crises in Zambia

description.narrative: The 4 target districts Solwezi, Kitwe, Livingstone and Chirundu are at-risk districts because of the geographical location and the state of infrastructure, the recent health update showed that the cases of covid-19 in the four districts were steadily rising, posing a huge risk of affecting many people

The project target will include; heath staff, volunteers, covid patients and families, people with chronic diseases and the general public. The project will target the 4 districts which have the following population 1. Kitwe 517543 2. Livingstone 139509 3. Chirundu 47 344 4. Solwezi 254 470 Total 958,866 people Based on resources available and capacity ZRCS will target 40% as direct beneficiaries = 383.546 people, whereas the remaining 60% will be targeted as the indirect population of 575,320 people. Of those, the project will target 50% females and 50%, males. The project will target at least 80 volunteers, 20 from each district. Beneficiaries will be selected in line with set criteria including age brackets. The beneficiary’s selection will include health staff, community leaders, branches and CBOs. Gender mainstreaming and consideration will be included at all levels of the project implementation. A needs assessment with a gender and inclusion lens is the first step in providing humanitarian assistance that is effective, safe and restores dignity

The project will be implemented within the communities of Solwezi district (North-western province), Kitwe district (Copperbelt), Chirundu district (Lusaka province) and Livingstone (Southern province). Solwezi and Kitwe are more mining and en route border towns linking Zambia to the DRC with the heavy traffic flow of goods (imports and exports) while Chirundu and Livingstone are more on crop agriculture, tourism, fishing and are also border towns with heavy traffic flows to neighbouring Zimbabwe. The location of the target districts possesses a huge risk of covid-19 transmission.

Strengthening flood response and preparedness in Bangui, Central African Republic.

description.narrative: Bangui, along the river Ubangi, remains under the threat of flooding, especially during the rainy season that will likely elapse due to climate change.
The Action will target the five CRCA local branches: 2nd, 3rd, 6th & 7th districts.

The Action will target the five CRCA local branches: 2nd, 3rd, 6th & 7th districts. Activities leverage the capacities built through other projects supported by Netherlands Red Cross (NLRC) and other Red Cross Movement partners and capitalize on them in terms of DP, protection, gender and inclusion (PGI) as well as Safer access; mitigation of impact from waterborne and other infectious diseases including Covid-19, protection of infrastructures and activation of tools such as contingency planning and early warning/early action.

The proposed Action will contribute to the delivery of a humanitarian preparedness for response to people likely to be affected by the flood and living under the threat of Covid-19 and potential violence from election process, by strengthening the response preparedness capacity of the CRCA to deliver a timely and efficient response.

title.narrative: Y-Cure 2: Youth Against Covid-19 Through Unified Response In Philippines.

description.narrative: Implementation throughout the 102 Chapters of the Philippine Red Cross
Philippine Community to be assisted via Helpline, Data Encoding and micro-grants.

The World Health Organization (WHO) on March 11 declared COVID-19 a pandemic, pointing to the over 118,000 cases of the coronavirus illness in over 110 countries and territories around the world and the sustained risk of further global spread. Some six months on there have been over 31 million cases and almost one million deaths. During this same period in the Philippines the cases have gone from below 50 to over 287,000 with a daily case rate of between 2000-4000/day.
The PRC recognized the need very early for PCR testing as a means to have a clearer picture of the case load in the country. It started its COVID testing operations by opening its first molecular laboratory, which has a total testing capacity of total of 4,000 tests a day, on April 14 at the mezzanine of its National Headquarters along EDSA. This was soon followed by another one at its Logistics and Multiple Center, just behind the National Headquarters, on April 29. Afterwards other molecular laboratories were also opened in Port Area, Manila, Clark, Subic, Batangas, Cebu, and Bacolod. The PRC molecular labs have been staffed by technical specialists and volunteers. Youth volunteers have been the backbone of the PRC HELPlines and data encoding of the patient details and reporting on results working on 24/7 rotating shifts. The NLRC via approval of its back donors recognized the importance of the HELPline and quickly realigned budgets to support these operations from May to September 2020. It is with the funding request document that the NLRC requests additional funds to continue the support to June 2021.

The population to be assisted through the project is twofold, firstly it is volunteers between 15-25 who will volunteer to support the implementation of the PRC COVID19 Response Plan and secondly those members in the community that will participate in the micro-grants/social protection projects.

The project aims at assisting the target population through several activities. These interventions can be put within the following categories based : (1). Support via HELPLINE. The support of the HELPLINE is open to all citizens of the Philippines who wish to book a COVID19 test, wish to reach out for technical guidance and support regarding COVID19 and it is envisaged will be utilised to support the roll out of the vaccination against COVID19 (2). Support through community level micro-grants. The micro-grants will target vulnerable communities with interventions related to COVID19. A set of established criteria have been developed and through the first phrases of the project implemented successfully. The criteria include community/community groups most vulnerable to COVID19, those communities have not received support from other agencies and those most vulnerable. Identified community actions are documented into minor proposals and submitted to the PRC NHQ for review and approval. (3). Psychosocial support to staff and volunteers. The project will establish a referral pathway to provide psychosocial support to staff and volunteers. The American Red Cross are currently supporting a research project on “the impact of COVID19 on the mental health of youth volunteers.” In discussion with the Youth Services Manager the recommendations from this report will guide the framework and methodology of the support mechanism to be provided to the volunteers

title.narrative: Gedaref Emergency Appeal bilateral support

description.narrative: Displaced populations currently depend on already limited access to clean, safe, and potable drinking water and water for domestic use in the host communities. If not controlled, it may bring competition and violence to access this scarce commodity between the refugees and the host communities. Further to this, the prevalence of COVID-19 and the potential for community transmission within informal and temporary shelter areas and arrangements must be considered as an essential focus in the need for water provision, hygiene training and improving hygiene practices, such as the use of hands-free washing stations.
Providing access to sanitation services and provision of hygiene items and promotion to refugees in Um Rakuba and Tunaidba.

SRCS will provide people in camps and host communities with improved access to safe drinking water, sanitation, and hygiene. This will be achieved through the provision of household water treatment and storage kits (buckets, jerrycans with lids); as well as water trucking if required. Community-level construction of latrines through provision of toilet slabs and training of local sanitationartisans who will further train the local communities in the construction of locally and culturally appropriate latrines will also be prioritized. Hygiene promotion and awareness sessions, as well as hygiene related supplies (hand sanitizer and soap), will be provided; and handwashing stations installed.

Targeted families will be assisted through interventions in shelter, livelihoods and basic needs, health, WASH, disaster risk reduction, community engagement and accountability as well as protection, gender and inclusion. Teams will adhere and practice all precautionary measures outlined in the Asia Pacific COVID-19-safe Best Practice Guide for Disaster response. The operation will be delivered in a manner that minimizes the risk of COVID-19 transmission for disaster-affected people.

title.narrative: Use of data & digital

description.narrative: Programme for 4 sub projects: 1. Digital Transformation of the IFRC Network 2. Setting up a Rapid prototyping service for the IFRC Network 3. Setting up Cash IM support service and products for National Societies and their partners 4. Content creation for data literacy in the IFRC Network and contribute to closing the digital divide 5. IFRCs DT strategy implementation through (cash) contribution 6. Data and Digital Support to NS (extension of the global covid project, similar to the MENA Data & Digital Support).

sector.narrative: Multisector aid for basic social services

title.narrative: Remotely supporting IFRC Digital Transformation Intervention Team

description.narrative: For 2 years, in a combination of a member of the IFRC Digital Acceleration team (1 FTE) and for Partnership Engagement (0.3FTE) seconded to the IFRC, and remote support of NLRC-510 team (0,5 FTE) on core topics such as digital program development, data science, data literacy, rapid prototyping, human centered design, data responsibility, digital maturity and strategy. The partnership engagement person will be tasked to create global deals with corporate sector and development banks to create a big package deal for the IFRC Network to fuel the digital strategy. This project will also support a number of NLRC bilateral partners to do a digital maturity assessment and develop a digital strategy or plan as part of the framework partnership agreement between NLRC and the National Society.

In virtually all countries, people increasingly rely on and expect a diverse range of digital services (e.g., through their mobile devices) to interact with local governments, companies, and community organizations and services. As noted in Strategy 2030, this change is also happening in humanitarian assistance. Yet, the Digital Divide remains a persistent and significant challenge at both national and local levels. The need for a successful and large-scale Digital Transformation is urgent. In fact, digital transformation is prioritized as one of seven transformations identified by the IFRC as required to confront the next decade’s main challenges. The IFRC’s Strategy 2030 highlights that effective integration of data analytics and digital technology, skills, and digital culture enables the network to harness its collective intelligence, multiply its impact, and democratize access to information. It goes accompanied with a competitive advantage – with better information, we are able to more accurately and more timely present the needs of the most vulnerable to donors, governments and the private sector, providing them with the assurance that their resources when partnering with RCRC are well spent. The Covid-19 crisis in particular has emphasized the importance of building data and digital capacity to enable us to keep track of the rapidly shifting vulnerabilities within the population. Digital Transformation is not only highlighted in the IFRC Strategy 2030, but also in the IFRC COVID Emergency appeal (latest revision, No3). The global pandemic has accelerated the need to scale-up data and digital transformation under the ‘new normal’. The IFRC COVID emergency appeal therefore mentions digital transformation as one of the three enabling actions.
Through supporting secondments and remote technical assistance to IFRC. Through supporting NLRC bilateral partners to do digital maturity assessments/develop digital strategies.

title.narrative: Other - People reached
People reached
Cash Information Management Service Development

description.narrative: NLRC-510 & 121 team British Red Cross Cash Hub IFRC Cash IM team National Societies

NLRC-510 will develop a Cash IM service and products, which will help national societies to implement cash programs supported by information management systems, digital technology and use data analytics to get good insights and reports. We will create a scale up and future plan for 121. The most feasible route to take with the system is to productize validated key components of it.

The objective of this project is to change the 510 development team to a rapid prototyping team with a clear global service offering to the IFRC Network, and to initiate a first set of support projects to national societies. When the service is initiated and national societies are requesting the services, the cost-recovery model of 510 will ensure the sustainability of the initial investment from the IH extra projects fund.

Within the IFRC Network more cash programs are planned and conducted than ever before. The current COVID appeal has already highlighted 22 national societies in the Africa region that will do cash programs for livelihoods. Many of those national societies have limited to no experience with cash programming. They find programmatic cash expertise through online courses and IFRC delegates. There however remains a gap in the IFRC Network on Cash Information Management experts. This gap is critical because the information management component in cash programming is significant. Additionally there is a big gap in training opportunities and standard toolkits for national societies to implement cash information management.

This is mainly due to the prolonged and escalating armed conflict which has been accompanied in 2020 with natural disasters of heavy rains and floods in addition of the onset of COVID-19 in a country with collapsed health system and high rates of poverty, food insecurity and malnutrition.

title.narrative: Other - People reached
People reached
Myanmar - Civil Unrest response

description.narrative: Civil Unrest Operation in Myanmar. Since 1 February 2021, Myanmar has been undergoing a political crisis with civil unrest precipitating a humanitarian crisis affecting populations across many parts of the country. The ongoing Civil Disobedience Movement (CDM) includes the critical sectors, of banking, health and transport. Banking limitations and a disrupted supply chain activity have added to increased food prices and limited access to cash at a national level. Economic impacts include job loss, particularly in peri-urban areas with already vulnerable populations facing food insecurity. Myanmar’s Public health system is also severely disrupted, reducing access for medical services, particularly for people with less income and access challenges.

Myanmar has a population of 52 million people1 across 330 townships within 17 states and regions. Within this evolving crisis, humanitarian needs are substantial across many regions and states. Critical factors include market disruptions, lack of access to basic services and social safety nets, and limited capacities across the country including for COVID-19 prevention and for disaster response. Requirements, therefore, include emergency and primary healthcare services, relief assistance and socio-economic support for affected populations across many of the 17 region and states

description.narrative: Beneficiaries are mild COVID-19 positive cases, indirect beneficiary are the hospitals as it will allow them to focus on serious COVID-19 cases (reducing stress on bed space)
Establishment and ongoing running support of COVID19 isolation facilities

Hospitals in the Philippines are overwhelmed with the number of COVID19 patients. Bed capacity in many hospitals have reached a critical point and worst case scenario of the COVID19 variant entering the Philippines it could get worse. Part of the challenges faced particularly in Metro Manila are patients being admitted for mild symptoms occupying critical bed space. The PRC is establishing "tent isolation facilities and working with the Depts of Education to use classrooms" as isolation facilities for mild COVID cases reducing the burden on the hospitals
Metro Manila currently, however situation is fluid and it may be realigned to other cities in the Philippines. In Metro Manila the PRC has already identified 10 isolation facility locations

The PRC will establish or convert existing structures for temporary isolation facilities it will provide ambulance services, set up isolation beds, provide supplementary hot meals, set up showers and latrines, It will coordinate with local government units for the establishment of the facilities, costs including establishment of facilities, ongoing running costs and volunteers allowances

title.narrative: Other - People reached
People reached
Strengthening institutional Disaster Preparedness and community level Epidemic Preparedness in Western Region, Uganda

description.narrative: 1. Enhance district level capacities by providing support in the development and operationalization of multi-hazard district contingency plans, improving EW systems and enhancing surge capacity. 2. Integrate Forecast-based Action into DCPs 3. Strengthen community-level epidemic preparedness by enhancing surveillance and referral systems to ensure early detection and response regarding diseases / events of public health concern. 4. Advocate for a National Disaster Preparedness and Management Law that incorporates anticipatory funding principles. 5. Ensure protection mainstreaming in all elements by enhancing responders' capacity on protection and accountability towards the population and the adaptation of protection into EW/EA mechanism.
11,864 local populations in the area. 5,000 displaced people
The Action targets distrits that are exposed to multiple hazards and are accepting new refugees, or are transit areas: * Kisoro * Ntoroko * Kanungu * Kasese * Isingiro * Kamwenge * Kyegegwa * Kikuube

The Action will strengthen the capacities of District Disaster Management Committees, District Task Forces and their local structures to establish well-functioning multi-hazard preparedness and response systems to ensure Early Warning and Early Action.

There is a clear need to strengthen DRM in Uganda to address the multiplicity of crises including epidemics, new refugee influxes and natural hazards. The most common and frequent hazards include floods, landslides, drought, earthquakes, hailstorms and windstorms. Since 2017, Uganda has experienced an influx of refugees from South Sudan and DRC and is now hosting 1,4 million refugees. In the coming time UNHCR predicts a large influx of refugees into the country. The scale of the refugee crisis continues to overwhelm national and local capacities. Active cross border movement combined with porous borders increases the risk of importation of epidemics (e.g. EVD). Besides, communities are often affected by Cholera, Typhoid Fever, Malaria and Diarrhoea. The COVID-19 global pandemic is widespread and is strongly impacting the health system, economy, livelihoods and protection.

sector.narrative: Multisector aid for basic social services

title.narrative: Other - People reached
People reached
Somaliland: building a network of human rights monitors

description.narrative: Following an initial assessment visit to the country in February 2017, this project sought to support a local partner organisation in Somaliland in their capacity to monitor, document and report on human rights violations and abuses. We trained local human rights monitors to investigate the abuses/violations happening on the ground, introduced them them to the basics of reporting and advocacy, and enhanced their basic (digital) security skills. The ultimate aim was to change the mindset/behavior of the government towards human rights defenders/journalists. While the project ended in July 2019, an evaluation of the project to draw on lessons learned was foreseen for 2020. In the context of covid-19 and related travel restrictions, priorities in 2020 shifted, and the idea to do an evaluation of this relatively small project was dropped.

title.narrative: Increased visibility and recognition of the partner to lobby/advocate for human rights through enhanced human rights monitoring and reporting capacity.
Increased visibility and recognition of the partner to lobby and advocate for human rights protection
Sudan: Investigating human rights violations by security forces

description.narrative: As a result of nationwide demonstrations in Sudan that started by mid-December 2018 and requested former President Omar al-Bashir to step down, activities in Sudan were put on hold in 2019. In 2020, work with our local partner was to restart following a field visit to Sudan in the first quarter of 2020, allowing for initial discussions on the contours of the follow-up project. Yet, due to covid-19, plans were further delayed.

Political unrest in Sudan in December 2018, brought Sudanese people to the streets to express their anger over the rising cost of living and erosion of political freedoms. The protests led to a military coup in April which overthrew the National Congress Party (NCP) government, and President al-Bashir and other senior party leaders were arrested. On 17 August 2019, after lengthy negotiations between the military and a coalition of opposition groups, the Constitutional Declaration was signed. It contained a new Bill of Rights strengthening the protection of human rights. On 21 August, the Transitional Military Council (TMC) was dissolved and a new Sovereign Council and Prime Minister were appointed. A new cabinet was formed in September 2019.
Despite these positive developments, the situation in Sudan remains highly volatile, as the country is marked by a deepening economic crisis. In addition, it cannot be ignored that the demonstrations were met with excessive use of force and unlawful killings by Sudanese security forces against peaceful protesters . Security forces used live ammunition against demonstrators, beat them on the streets and in hospitals and arbitrarily detained thousands who faced torture and other ill-treatment in detention. These violations mainly remain under investigation.

title.narrative: Enhanced monitoring and reporting capacity of human rights monitoring teams
Strenghtened capacity of human rights monitors in Sudan
Business and Human Rights: Building local capacity to counter corporate human rights abuses

description.narrative: In Africa, as well other parts of the world, globalisation triggered that non-state actors including transnational corporations and other businesses have gradually become more powerful and influential, bringing new challenges in the field of human rights. Increasingly, local communities have been confronted with human rights abuses committed by businesses, whether through poor labour conditions, forced evictions or the destruction of their livelihoods as a result of e.g. logging, mining and pollution. Although governments have the obligation to protect people from such abuses, many fail to do so. Over the years, the United Nations human rights machinery has tried to clarify the respective roles and responsibilities of governments and businesses with regard to protecting and respecting human rights. Yet, there are still few effective mechanisms at (inter)national level that prevent and address corporate abuses. Moreover, local people and communities often do not know their rights or how to seek justice for the corporate abuses they are confronted with. They lack access to information; are excluded from decision-making processes; or face ineffective legal systems and/or corruption.

To help local organisations, activists, and grassroots communities better understand their rights against corporate interests, as well as the respective roles and responsibilities of businesses and governments, AINL/HURICAP has developed a capacity-building package comprised of a handbook series and training modules. While the training package is in its final development stage, it needs further testing and piloting, which is on hold due to the covid-19 crisis.

title.narrative: Development of a training package consisting of handbooks and a training modules to help build the capacty of local activists and grassroots organisations in defending their rights against corporate interests.
Availability of a training package on business and human rights, targeting local activists and grassroots organisations.

title.narrative: DRA Babile Oromia and Moyale Somali Region Desert Locust Response

description.narrative:
Emergency Desert Locust  Response in Babile Woreda (Oromia) and Moyale woreda (Somali  Region). 

Key objective: people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihood assets
Specific objective: addressing the most urgent needs of 27.395 desert locust affected people by providing MPC, emergency livelihood assistance and WASH support related to COVID-19.

Target group: A total of 27.395 individual beneficiaries (M:4931, W:6027, G:9040, B:7397) will be targeted.

Main activities:
- Distribution of specialized crop and grass seeds and farming tools, restocking of livestock for female-headed households and capacity building on DL control at the community level,

- Provision of MPC (Multi-Purpose Cash),

- Intervention to prevent the spread of COVID-19, such as distribution of Hygiene Kits, hygiene promotion and Installation/reparation of boreholes.

comment.narrative: This comprises recruited hygiene promoters, community nutrition mobilizers, community committees, community leaders and participants of community engagement and feedback meetings. title.narrative: CHS-R1 Unconditional and unrestricted cash

description.narrative: CHSR1 - CHS-R1 Unconditional and unrestricted cash

title.narrative: CHS-I1 - Number of people benefitting from unconditional and unrestricted cash

description.narrative: 8 months of multipurpose cash for 1630 individuals in Monguno LGA and 5 months of multipurpose cash for 1000 individuals in Mafa LGA

comment.narrative:
A total of 6,045 individuals received cash: 3,228 under NJR2019 top-up and 2,817 under the regular NJR2020 MPC.
Beneficiaries reached under NJR2019 top-up (Monguno): 3,228 individuals, 51.2% females were reached. Of this number, 2,359 received a monthly per capital transfer value of NGN6,940 over the period of six months. 2,171 individuals collected 6 tranches; 159 individuals collected 5 tranches; 6 individuals collected 4 tranches and 33 individuals collected 1 tranche totaling 2,359 individuals or 102.56% of the original project target of 2,300 individuals to receive 6 rounds of cash.
Due to underspend on vendors commission and other budget lines, ZOA provided one round of emergency multipurpose cash to 869 fire victims within the project location. The per capital transfer amount was NGN3,595. 2,359 individuals reached under the original target + 869 reached with one-time emergency cash gives a total of 3,228 individuals reached.
Beneficiaries reached under NJR2020 (Mafa/Monguno): 2,817 individuals received multipurpose cash in Monguno and Mafa under the regular NJR project. Of this number, Monguno accounts for 1,778 while Mafa accounts for 1,039 individuals referred by SCI for cash support. Cash collection rate in Mafa was 99.9% while that of Monguno was 99.7%. Due to delays by EFCC to issue cash clearance, the transfer in Monguno was short by two months, 6 instead of 8 rounds.

title.narrative: FSC-COV-R3 Prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic related to Food Security & Livelihoods

description.narrative: COVR3 - COV-FSC-R3 Prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic related to Food Security & Livelihoods

title.narrative: FSC-COV-I3 - Number of people receiving COVID-19 related assistance (FS&L)

description.narrative: Cash provided to individuals with protection concerns for food

comment.narrative:
Four protection organizations referred 295 households with protection concerns for cash support. These households contained 1,016 individuals. 98.5% of cash electronically transferred to these households was redeemed. The remaining 1.5% accounts for households that left the project areas before end of project as well as those excluded for varying reasons. For example, a household was referred twice by two protection organizations.
The protection organizations that ZOA worked with are: IRC and PUI (two international organizations) and GISCOR and HARAF (two national organizations)

description.narrative: Distribution of COVID-19 kits and conduct of COVID-19 prevention

comment.narrative: Figure represents individuals that received messages on COVID prevention/COVID awareness.

title.narrative: LOC-R3 Capacity building (Reach)
LOC-I3 - Number of national and local actors supported with capacity-building

description.narrative: Conduct training for community volunteers, local staff and community leaders on project activities

comment.narrative: This comprises recruited hygiene promoters, community nutrition mobilizers, community committees, community leaders and participants of community engagement and feedback meetings. Hygiene promoters received training on conducting hygiene promotion and safety measures, especially during COVID. They all received training on PSEA, accountability to affected population and the ZOA's complaints and response mechanisms. WASHCOM members received training in repair and minor maintenance of hand pumps.

title.narrative: WSH-R1 Hygiene promotion
WSH-I1 - Number of people having regular access to soap to meet hygienic needs

description.narrative: 1,200 households benefit from both hygiene promotion and soap for laundry and bathing

comment.narrative: 1,196 households/families or 8262 individuals (137.7% of target) have benefitted from the distribution of soaps to meet up with daily basic hygiene needs. The soaps include 3 pieces of laundry soaps (200g) and 13 pieces of bathing soaps (250g). The number of beneficiaries reported represents the actual household membership reached.

title.narrative: WSH-R2 Excreta Disposal
WSH-I2 - Number of people having access to dignified, safe, clean and functional excreta disposal facilities

description.narrative: Construction and rehabilitation of 95 stances of latrines and 50 units of bathing shelters

comment.narrative: Additional 20 stances were constructed to the initially constructed 95 stances across 3 of the 5 communities (Zannari, Simari and Mala Kyariri); making a total of 115 stances of latrines. This was because there were still needs and the budget allowed ZOA to fill the gaps by constructing additional stances of latrines and bathing shelters. Additionally, 18 stances of bathing shelters were constructed across 3 of the 5 communities where the needs persisted. These additional latrines and bathing shelters were constructed as stand-alone (a block of one) and were all gender segregated and marked. ZOA worked with the communities in selecting the locations for latrines and bathing shelters and in identifying areas with the most needs.

title.narrative: WSH-R3 Drainage
WSH-I3 - Number of people living in settlements with a functional drainage network

description.narrative: Cleaning of drainages within residential areas of targeted beneficiaries

comment.narrative: The drainage cleaning equipment were distributed across all 5 communities. Equipment include; Diggers (50), Wheel barrows (25), Shovels (50), Hand gloves (50), Gum boots (50), Metallic rakes (10) and Water pump set (1). Materials purchased were recommended by respective communities during feedback meetings. All equipment were left in the custody of the communities' respective leader's households and intending users collected these equipment, use them and refund them when they are done so other groups could also have access to the tools. This was also a suggestion from the community members during one of the feedback meetings as the equipment was not enough for distribution in smaller clusters. All 8262 individuals who received soap reside in these locations.

title.narrative: WSH-R4 Water Supply
WSH-I4 - Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Construction/rehabilitation of 2 solar boreholes to provide water access to affected population

comment.narrative: The 2 solar powered boreholes drilled in June were fully equipped and commissioned in July 2020 and one additional solar powered borehole was rehabilitated in Simari community bringing the total number of solar boreholes to 3 to benefit 9000 individuals. The borehole is equipped with 20 cubic meters overhead water tank with reticulation to 1 fetching point which has 10 tap heads. Due to existing water gaps and on the request of the community, ZOA repaired/rehabilitated 7 dysfunctional handpumps in Mala Kyariri and Simari communities to benefit 3,500 individuals

title.narrative: WSH-R6 Hygiene promotion (Awareness)
WSH-I6 - Number of people reached with hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities

description.narrative: Hygiene promoters conduct hygiene promotion activities in project communities

comment.narrative: 9 additional hygiene promoters (5 males and 4 females) were recruited locally to add to the existing 16 hygiene promoters; making a total of 25 hygiene promoters (10 males and 15 females). This was done to increase the reach of hygiene promotion and COVID - 19 awareness messages. Beneficiaries were reached through door to door visits only as per recommended by the WaSH sector due to the COVID - 19. All hygiene promoters were equipped with nose masks and hand sanitizers and maintained social distance during sensitization sessions. The increase in household membership benefiting from hygiene promotion was due to the existence of households with larger membership as well as the willingness of other households to participate in hygiene promotion sessions.

title.narrative: Syria Joint Response 2020 (Lead Agency): Dutch Relief Alliance - NGOs Joint Humanitarian Response to the Syria Crisis

description.narrative: Overall goal SJR2020: Improved wellbeing of conflict-affected people inside Syria, especially the most vulnerable. Interventions will be done in the areas of Food Security and Livelihoods, Health, Individual household shelter, Protection and Multi-Purpose Cash.

SJR2020 will focus on Syria, targeting the most vulnerable households. Within Syria the choice has been made to concentrate on Aleppo and Rural Damascus. It is anticipated that SJR2020 will reach around 111.533 beneficiaries

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 4130 7320 AC Apeldoorn The Netherlands

sector.narrative: Health, NFIs and Shelter, WASH, Multi-purpose cash

title.narrative: Syria Joint Response 2020

description.narrative:
The project will rehabilitate domestic shelter for vulnerable families in Aleppo, including household adaptations for people living with mobility impairment. This activity is carried out by ZOAs partner Medair.

In Aleppo and Rural Damascus, ZOA will work with GOPA-DERD to identify most vulnerable families for vocational training in subjects likely to provide a future income for the households. Participants will also receive lifeskills training, and cash for attendance while undergoing the training. 

The activities are closely coordinated with other SJR partners, to facilitate referrals of beneficiaries, and joint learning.

Covid-19: The Covid-19 project aims to provide essential water, sanitation and personal hygiene goods and services for preparedness and prevention of COVID-19 to 9, 000 vulnerable individuals in Nashabiyeh (Duma, Rural Damascus). The main project activities are: -distribution of hygiene kits -installation of household water tanks -communication of critical risk information. CHS: The overall expected result by the end of 2020 is that ZOA Syria Response and its local partners operate more in line with the ZOA standard ‘Way of Working’, thereby strengthening adherence also to the Core Humanitarian Standards. Funding is within the SJR fund, a budget of 22,000 EUR has been allocated to accountability/CHS. Project Objectives are: 1. Strengthened accountability for affected populations 2. ZOA Management team is equipped to lead and manage staff 3. ZOA programmes are conflict sensitive 4. ZOA has more and better equipped local partners

Increase member involvement through the association activities to increase revenue and membership base

description.narrative: 2019 PlanPlanned activities include My.Coop Aggregation training Youth workshop FM coaching development of extension strategy2020 PlanExchange Business visit to PDFA Advanced Record Keeping (Might be skipped due to Covid Financial management training Governance training and Youth council masterclass and development of extension strategy for 2020

The mian objcetive of CDFA is to diversify their income sources and increasing their capital base and reducing on donor dependency. The association also realizes the need to increase its membership base and involving youths and women as it has an impact on their revenue. However the association sees the need to provide more member services to its members as a way of proving its relevance need for members to affiliate. BHAG 2021: A financially self-sustaining organisation providing quality services to 4 750 members towards a profitable agribusiness by focusing on improved crop production promoting mixed-farming and improved marketing. Objectives: Increasing membership to 4750 and becoming a financially self sustaining organisation

The project will focus on increasing revenue for the association through member involvement and provision of extension services. It will also tackle the issue of youth and gender inclusiveness to help youth participation in the development of the district through the association. They will be coaching in financial management to help the organisation put internal controls and assess the business's potentil to grow.
